Peter stepped out of the freezing night air and into the brightly lit hospital lobby, holding his three-year-old daughter in his arms. The harsh light made her look even more unwell, her face all red and sweaty. Her fever had started suddenly, just before dinner, but it wouldn't go down despite his efforts. At the front desk, he explained her symptoms, his concern growing with every moment. They were quickly led to the doctor, who reassured him and carefully examined his daughter. After the doctor gave her a shot, her fever went down and she seemed more comfortable. As Peter watched her sleep peacefully that night, he felt a wave of calm wash over him.

Imagine you have the best tea in the world and you put it into a bag that's impermeable. It won't work. You just won't be able to make a cup of tea. For the teabag to work, it needs to be porous. You need the tea and the water to come in contact with each other. In our lives too, we cannot survive and thrive in isolation. Leaders need to be careful not to build walls around themselves that prevent people from reaching out to them. As a leader, you need to be able to touch other people. The tea was meant to mix with the water. Similarly all of us were designed to work with other people, with teams, and with society at large.

annotations.html: 다음 글에서 필자가 주장하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?
annotations.text: 다음 글에서 필자가 주장하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?

It is difficult, if not impossible, to define the limits which reason should impose on the desire for wealth; for there is no absolute or definite amount of wealth which will satisfy a man. The amount is always relative, that is to say, just so much as will maintain the proportion between what he wants and what he gets; for to measure a man's happiness only by what he gets, and not also by what he expects to get, is as pointless as to try and express a fraction which shall have a numerator but no denominator. A man never feels the loss of things which it never occurs to him to ask for; he is just as happy without them; whilst another, who may have a hundred times as much, feels miserable because he has not got the one thing he wants. In fact, every man has a horizon of his own, and he will expect as much as he thinks it is possible for him to get.

All of the restaurants are using carefully chosen words to evoke vivid mental images of delicious food and rich desserts in order to draw the potential customer to their particular establishment. Just like the restaurants, nature has its own dining establishments. In a fashion similar to the restaurants' financial dependence upon drawing in many customers, the restaurateurs of the natural world (i.e., flowers) must also attract potential diners to sample their offerings. In the natural world, there are no neon signs or flashy words in which to market a potential meal to hungry animals. These restaurants that I am referring to are the world's flowers, and the potential guests are the host of organisms that visit flowers to obtain nectar and other valuable resources. Instead of using a written language or neon sign, they advertise their offerings just as effectively using the language of smell.

Would you rather receive $1,000 in a year or $1,100 in a year and a month? Most people will opt for the larger sum in thirteen months — where else will you find a monthly interest rate of 10 percent. A wise choice, since the interest will compensate you generously for any risks you face by waiting the extra few weeks. Second question: Would you prefer $1,000 today cash on the table or $1,100 in a month? If you think like most people, you'll take the $1,000 right away. This is amazing. In both cases, if you hold out for just a month longer, you get $100 more. In the first case, it's simple enough. You figure: "I've already waited twelve months; what's one more?" Not in the second case. The introduction of "now" causes us to make inconsistent decisions. Science calls this phenomenon hyperbolic discounting. The closer a reward is, the higher our "emotional interest rate" rises and the more we are willing to give up in exchange for it.

Peter stepped out of the freezing night air and into the brightly lit hospital lobby, holding his three-year-old daughter in his arms. The harsh light made her look even more unwell, her face all red and sweaty. Her fever had started suddenly, just before dinner, but it wouldn't go down despite his efforts. At the front desk, he explained her symptoms, his concern growing with every moment. They were quickly led to the doctor, who reassured him and carefully examined his daughter. After the doctor gave her a shot, her fever went down and she seemed more comfortable. As Peter watched her sleep peacefully that night, he felt a wave of calm wash over him.

annotations.text: 다음 글의 요지로 가장 적절한 것은?

It is difficult, if not impossible, to define the limits which reason should impose on the desire for wealth; for there is no absolute or definite amount of wealth which will satisfy a man. The amount is always relative, that is to say, just so much as will maintain the proportion between what he wants and what he gets; for to measure a man's happiness only by what he gets, and not also by what he expects to get, is as pointless as to try and express a fraction which shall have a numerator but no denominator. A man never feels the loss of things which it never occurs to him to ask for; he is just as happy without them; whilst another, who may have a hundred times as much, feels miserable because he has not got the one thing he wants. In fact, every man has a horizon of his own, and he will expect as much as he thinks it is possible for him to get.

To determine the mass of my bowling ball, I might put it onto a balance and compare it with a known mass, such as a number of metal cubes each weighing 1, 10, or 100 grams. Things get much more complicated if 1 want to know the mass of a distant star. How do I measure it? We can roughly say that measuring the mass of a star involves various theories. If we want to measure the mass of a binary star, we first determine a center of mass between the two stars, then their distance from that center which we can then use, together with a value for the period and a certain instance of Kepler's Third Law, to calculate the mass. In other words, in order to "measure" the star mass, we measure other quantities and use those values, together with certain equations, to calculate the mass. Measurement is not a simple and unmediated estimation of independently existing properties, but a determination of certain magnitudes before the background of a number of accepted theories.

Would you rather receive $1,000 in a year or $1,100 in a year and a month? Most people will opt for the larger sum in thirteen months — where else will you find a monthly interest rate of 10 percent. A wise choice, since the interest will compensate you generously for any risks you face by waiting the extra few weeks. Second question: Would you prefer $1,000 today cash on the table or $1,100 in a month? If you think like most people, you'll take the $1,000 right away. This is amazing. In both cases, if you hold out for just a month longer, you get $100 more. In the first case, it's simple enough. You figure: "I've already waited twelve months; what's one more?" Not in the second case. The introduction of "now" causes us to make inconsistent decisions. Science calls this phenomenon hyperbolic discounting. The closer a reward is, the higher our "emotional interest rate" rises and the more we are willing to give up in exchange for it.

All of the restaurants are using carefully chosen words to evoke vivid mental images of delicious food and rich desserts in order to draw the potential customer to their particular establishment. Just like the restaurants, nature has its own dining establishments. In a fashion similar to the restaurants' financial dependence upon drawing in many customers, the restaurateurs of the natural world (i.e., flowers) must also attract potential diners to sample their offerings. In the natural world, there are no neon signs or flashy words in which to market a potential meal to hungry animals. These restaurants that I am referring to are the world's flowers, and the potential guests are the host of organisms that visit flowers to obtain nectar and other valuable resources. Instead of using a written language or neon sign, they advertise their offerings just as effectively using the language of smell.

A man never feels the loss of things which it never occurs to him to ask for; he is just as happy without them; whilst another, who may have a hundred times as much, feels miserable because he has not got the one thing he wants. In fact, every man has a horizon of his own, and he will expect as much as he thinks it is possible for him to get.

annotations.text: 다음 글의 제목으로 가장 적절한 것은?

Would you rather receive $1,000 in a year or $1,100 in a year and a month? Most people will opt for the larger sum in thirteen months — where else will you find a monthly interest rate of 10 percent. A wise choice, since the interest will compensate you generously for any risks you face by waiting the extra few weeks. Second question: Would you prefer $1,000 today cash on the table or $1,100 in a month? If you think like most people, you'll take the $1,000 right away. This is amazing. In both cases, if you hold out for just a month longer, you get $100 more. In the first case, it's simple enough. You figure: "I've already waited twelve months; what's one more?" Not in the second case. The introduction of "now" causes us to make inconsistent decisions. Science calls this phenomenon hyperbolic discounting. The closer a reward is, the higher our "emotional interest rate" rises and the more we are willing to give up in exchange for it.

A wise choice, since the interest will compensate you generously for any risks you face by waiting the extra few weeks. Second question: Would you prefer ＄1,000 today cash on the table or ＄1,100 in a month? If you think like most people, you'll take the $1,000 right away. This is amazing. In both cases, if you hold out for just a month longer, you get ＄100 more. In the first case, it's simple enough. You figure: "I've already waited twelve months; what's one more?" Not in the second case. The introduction of "now" causes us to make __________ decisions. Science calls this phenomenon hyperbolic discounting. The closer a reward is, the higher our "emotional interest rate" rises and the more we are willing to give up in exchange for it.

annotations.html: It is difficult, if not impossible, to define the limits which reason should impose on the desire for wealth; for there is no absolute or definite amount of wealth which will satisfy a man. The amount is always relative, that is to say, just so much as will maintain the proportion between what he wants and what he gets; for to measure a man's happiness only by what he gets, and not also by what he expects to get, is as pointless as to try and express a fraction which shall have a numerator but no denominator. A man never feels the loss of things which it never occurs to him to ask for; he is just as happy without them; whilst another, who may have a hundred times as much, feels miserable because he has not got the one thing he wants. ① In fact, every man has a horizon of his own, and he will expect as much as he thinks it is possible for him to get. ② Wealth accumulation strategies vary greatly across different cultures and historical periods. ③ For this reason, contentment is not an absolute state but depends on the relation between what we have and what we desire. ④ The most efficient way to increase happiness is often to reduce desires rather than increase possessions. ⑤ This subjective nature of satisfaction explains why wealth alone cannot guarantee happiness.

It is difficult, if not impossible, to define the limits which reason should impose on the desire for wealth; for there is no absolute or definite amount of wealth which will satisfy a man. The amount is always relative, that is to say, just so much as will maintain the proportion between what he wants and what he gets; for to measure a man's happiness only by what he gets, and not also by what he expects to get, is as pointless as to try and express a fraction which shall have a numerator but no denominator. A man never feels the loss of things which it never occurs to him to ask for; he is just as happy without them; whilst another, who may have a hundred times as much, feels miserable because he has not got the one thing he wants. In fact, every man has a horizon of his own, and he will expect as much as he thinks it is possible for him to get.

Not in the second case. The introduction of "now" causes us to make inconsistent decisions. Science calls this phenomenon hyperbolic discounting. The closer a reward is, the higher our "emotional interest rate" rises and the more we are willing to give up in exchange for it.

It is difficult, if not impossible, to define the limits which reason should impose on the desire for wealth; for there is no absolute or definite amount of wealth which will satisfy a man. The amount is always relative, that is to say, just so much as will maintain the proportion between what he wants and what he gets; for to measure a man's happiness only by what he gets, and not also by what he expects to get, is as pointless as to try and express a fraction which shall have a numerator but no denominator. A man never feels the loss of things which it never occurs to him to ask for; he is just as happy without them; whilst another, who may have a hundred times as much, feels miserable because he has not got the one thing he wants. In fact, every man has a horizon of his own, and he will expect as much as he thinks it is possible for him to get.

annotations.html:
① The desire for wealth does not have clear boundaries that can be easily defined by reason.
② A person's satisfaction with wealth depends on the relationship between what they want and what they obtain.
③ People do not miss possessions they never think to desire in the first place.
④ People with greater wealth are generally happier than those with less wealth.
⑤ Each individual has their own expectations based on what they perceive as attainable.

Instead of using a written language or neon sign, they advertise their offerings just as effectively using the language of smell.

Would you rather receive $1,000 in a year or $1,100 in a year and a month? Most people will opt for the larger sum in thirteen months — where else will you find a monthly interest rate of 10 percent. A wise choice, since the interest will compensate you generously for any risks you face by waiting the extra few weeks. Second question: Would you prefer $1,000 today cash on the table or $1,100 in a month? If you think like most people, you'll take the $1,000 right away. This is amazing. In both cases, if you hold out for just a month longer, you get $100 more. In the first case, it's simple enough. You figure: "I've already waited twelve months; what's one more?" Not in the second case. The introduction of "now" causes us to make inconsistent decisions. Science calls this phenomenon hyperbolic discounting. The closer a reward is, the higher our "emotional interest rate" rises and the more we are willing to give up in exchange for it.

annotations.html:
① Most people choose $1,100 in thirteen months over $1,000 in a year.
② People tend to take $1,000 immediately rather than wait a month for $1,100.
③ Hyperbolic discounting leads people to make more rational financial decisions.
④ Our emotional interest rate increases as rewards become more immediate.
⑤ The monthly interest rate in the first scenario is approximately 10 percent.
annotations.text:
① Most people choose $1,100 in thirteen months over $1,000 in a year.
② People tend to take $1,000 immediately rather than wait a month for $1,100.
③ Hyperbolic discounting leads people to make more rational financial decisions.
④ Our emotional interest rate increases as rewards become more immediate.
⑤ The monthly interest rate in the first scenario is approximately 10 percent.

They were quickly led to the doctor, who reassured him and carefully examined his daughter. After the doctor gave her a shot, her fever went down and she seemed more comfortable. As Peter watched her sleep peacefully that night, he felt a wave of calm wash over him.

You need the tea and the water to come in contact with each other. In our lives too, we cannot survive and thrive in isolation. Leaders need to be careful not to build walls around themselves that prevent people from reaching out to them. As a leader, __________. The tea was meant to mix with the water. Similarly all of us were designed to work with other people, with teams, and with society at large.

It is difficult, if not impossible, to define the limits which reason should impose on the desire for wealth; for there is no absolute or definite amount of wealth which will satisfy a man. The amount is always relative, that is to say, just so much as will maintain the proportion between what he wants and what he gets; for to measure a man's happiness only by what he gets, and not also by what he expects to get, is __________ which shall have a numerator but no denominator. A man never feels the loss of things which it never occurs to him to ask for; he is just as happy without them; whilst another, who may have a hundred times as much, feels miserable because he has not got the one thing he wants. In fact, every man has a horizon of his own, and he will expect as much as he thinks it is possible for him to get

Just like the restaurants, nature has its own dining establishments. In a fashion similar to the restaurants' financial dependence upon drawing in many customers, __________ must also attract potential diners to sample their offerings. In the natural world, there are no neon signs or flashy words in which to market a potential meal to hungry animals. These restaurants that I am referring to are the world's flowers, and the potential guests are the host of organisms that visit flowers to obtain nectar and other valuable resources. Instead of using a written language or neon sign, they advertise their offerings just as effectively using the language of smell

Would you rather receive $1,000 in a year or $1,100 in a year and a month? Most people will opt for the larger sum in thirteen months — __________ of 10 percent. A wise choice, since the interest will compensate you generously for any risks you face by waiting the extra few weeks. Second question: Would you prefer $1,000 today cash on the table or $1,100 in a month? If you think like most people, you'll take the $1,000 right away. This is amazing. In both cases, if you hold out for just a month longer, you get $100 more. In the first case, it's simple enough. You figure: "I've already waited twelve months; what's one more?" Not in the second case. The introduction of "now" causes us to make inconsistent decisions. Science calls this phenomenon hyperbolic discounting. The closer a reward is, the higher our "emotional interest rate" rises and the more we are willing to give up in exchange for it.

(2) A man never feels the loss of things which it never occurs to him to ask for; he is just as happy without them; whilst another, who may have a hundred times as much, feels miserable because he has not got the one thing he wants.
(3) It is difficult, if not impossible, to define the limits which reason should impose on the desire for wealth; for there is no absolute or definite amount of wealth which will satisfy a man.
(4) In fact, every man has a horizon of his own, and he will expect as much as he thinks it is possible for him to get.

annotations.html: ​해설: 이 글은 부에 대한 욕망의 한계를 정의하기 어렵다고 하면서, 행복은 단순히 얻은 것만으로 측정할 수 없고 얻기를 기대하는 것과의 비율로 측정해야 한다고 주장한다. 글에서는 이를 분수에 비유하여 분자(얻은 것)만 있고 분모(기대하는 것)가 없는 분수를 표현하는 것처럼 무의미하다고 설명하고 있다. 따라서 행복은 소유한 부와 기대하는 부 사이의 비율에 따라 결정된다는 것이 글의 요지이다.

annotations.html: 이 글은 쌍곡 할인(hyperbolic discounting)이라는 현상을 설명하고 있다. 1년 후 $1,000과 13개월 후 $1,100 중에서는 대부분이 13개월 후의 더 큰 금액을 선택하지만, 당장의 $1,000과 한 달 후 $1,100 중에서는 당장의 적은 금액을 선택하는 경향이 있다. 이는 보상이 현재에 가까울수록 사람들의 '감정적 이자율'이 높아져 더 많은 것을 포기하게 된다는 것을 보여준다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 식당이 고객을 유치하기 위해 매력적인 단어를 사용하는 것처럼, 자연계의 식당인 꽃들도 잠재적 손님인 동물들을 유치하기 위한 방법이 있다고 설명한다. 글에서는 "the restaurateurs of the natural world (i.e., flowers)"라고 꽃을 자연계의 식당 주인으로 비유하고 있으며, "they advertise their offerings just as effectively using the language of smell"라고 언급하여 꽃이 향기라는 언어를 통해 광고한다는 핵심 내용을 담고 있다. 따라서 꽃을 자연의 식당으로 비유하고 향기를 광고 수단으로 사용한다는 내용을 담은 제목이 가장 적절하다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 사람들이 보상의 시간적 거리에 따라 비일관적인 의사결정을 하는 현상을 설명하고 있다. 1년 후 $1,000과 13개월 후 $1,100 사이에서는 대부분 13개월을 기다려 더 많은 금액을 선택하지만, 지금 당장 $1,000 과 한 달 후 $1,100 사이에서는 즉각적인 보상을 선호하는 경향이 있다. 글에서 "The introduction of 'now' causes us to make inconsistent decisions. Science calls this phenomenon hyperbolic discounting"라고 명시하며 이러한 현상을 쌍곡선 할인(hyperbolic discounting)이라고 설명하고 있으므로, 즉각적인 보상이 우리의 결정을 왜곡시키는 현상에 관한 제목이 가장 적절하다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 부에 대한 욕망과 행복의 상대적 성격에 관한 내용이다. 글에서는 행복을 측정할 때 단순히 얻은 것만으로 측정하는 것이 아니라, 기대하는 것과의 비율로 측정해야 한다고 설명한다. 이는 분수에서 분자만 있고 분모가 없는 것처럼 무의미하다는 비유로 강조되며, 이어지는 내용에서도 사람의 행복이 실제 소유량보다는 기대와 욕구에 따라 달라진다고 설명하고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 식당과 자연계의 꽃을 비교하면서, 식당이 고객을 유치하기 위해 언어를 사용하는 것처럼 꽃도 방문자를 유치해야 한다는 내용이다. 빈칸 앞에서 '내가 언급하는 이 식당들은 세계의 꽃들'이라고 했고, 빈칸 뒤에는 '꽃을 방문하여 꿀과 다른 귀중한 자원을 얻는 생물체들'이라고 설명하고 있다. 또한 글의 앞부분에서 '잠재적 고객(potential customer)'이라는 표현이 사용되었으므로, 꽃을 방문하는 생물체들은 '잠재적 손님들(the potential guests)'이라고 표현하는 것이 가장 적절하다.

annotations.html: 해설: 지문은 사람들이 보상이 즉각적일 때와 미래에 있을 때 다르게 반응하는 현상인 쌍곡 할인(hyperbolic discounting)을 설명하고 있다. 보상이 가까울수록 사람들 의 행동(behavior)이 더 비합리적(irrational)으로 변하는 것을 보여준다. 이는 "the introduction of now causes us to make inconsistent decisions"와 "the closer a reward is, the higher our emotional interest rate rises"라는 문장에서 명확히 드러난다.

(1) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면 Peter의 딸은 3살이었다. "Peter stepped out of the freezing night air and into the brightly lit hospital lobby, holding his three-year-old daughter in his arms."라고 명시되어 있다.
(2) 해설: 열은 저녁 식사 전에 갑자기 시작되었다. 텍스트에서 "Her fever had started suddenly, just before dinner, but it wouldn't go down despite his efforts."라고 언급되어 있다.
(3) 해설: 병원 직원들은 Peter와 그의 딸을 빠르게 의사에게 안내했다. 텍스트에 "They were quickly led to the doctor, who reassured him and carefully examined his daughter."라고 명시되어 있다.
(4) 해설: 의사가 Peter의 딸에게 주사를 놓았다. 텍스트에 "After the doctor gave her a shot, her fever went down and she seemed more comfortable."라고 언급되어 있다.
(5) 해설: Peter는 그날 밤 딸이 평화롭게 자는 것을 지켜보며 평온함을 느꼈다. 텍스트에서 "As Peter watched her sleep peacefully that night, he felt a wave of calm wash over him."라고 설명되어 있다.

(1) 해설: 불침투성 티백은 차와 물이 섞이는 것을 허용하지 않는다. 텍스트에서 "Imagine you have the best tea in the world and you put it into a bag that's impermeable. It won't work. You just won't be able to make a cup of tea."라고 명시되어 있다.
(2) 해설: 텍스트는 티백 비유를 사용하여 인간 관계를 설명한다. "In our lives too, we cannot survive and thrive in isolation"이라는 문장에서 티백 비유를 인간 연결성에 적용하고 있다.
(3) 해설: 텍스트는 리더가 장벽을 만들지 말아야 한다고 강조한다. "Leaders need to be careful not to build walls around themselves that prevent people from reaching out to them."이라고 명시되어 있다.
(4) 해설: 텍스트는 인간이 고립되어 일하도록 설계되지 않았다고 주장한다. "Similarly all of us were designed to work with other people, with teams, and with society at large."라고 명시되어 있다.
(5) 해설: 텍스트는 차와 인간 모두 환경과 상호작용할 때 가장 잘 기능한다고 암시한다. "The tea was meant to mix with the water. Similarly all of us were designed to work with other people"라는 부분에서 이를 확인할 수 있다.

annotations.html:
해설: 텍스트에 따르면 "there is no absolute or definite amount of wealth which will satisfy a man"이라고 명시되어 있다. 즉, 사람을 만족시킬 수 있는 절대적이거나 명확한 부의 양은 없다.
해설: 텍스트는 "to measure a man's happiness only by what he gets, and not also by what he expects to get, is as pointless as to try and express a fraction which shall have a numerator but no denominator"라고 설명한다. 이는 행복을 측정할 때 얻은 것뿐만 아니라 기대하는 것도 고려해야 함을 의미한다.
해설: 텍스트에서 "another, who may have a hundred times as much, feels miserable because he has not got the one thing he wants"라고 언급하고 있다. 이는 많은 부를 가지고 있더라도 원하는 한 가지가 없으면 불행을 느낄 수 있음을 보여준다.
해설: 텍스트에 "A man never feels the loss of things which it never occurs to him to ask for; he is just as happy without them"이라고 명시되어 있다. 이는 사람들이 요구하거나 생각하지 않는 것들에 대해서는 그것의 부재를 느끼지 않는다는 의미이다.
해설: 텍스트의 마지막 문장 "every man has a horizon of his own, and he will expect as much as he thinks it is possible for him to get"에서 모든 사람은 자신만의 기대치(horizon)를 가지고 있으며, 자신이 얻을 수 있다고 생각하는 만큼을 기대한다고 설명하고 있다.

해설: 텍스트의 첫 문장에서 "All of the restaurants are using carefully chosen words to evoke vivid mental images of delicious food and rich desserts in order to draw the potential customer to their particular establishment."라고 명시하고 있다.
해설: 텍스트에서 "the restaurateurs of the natural world (i.e., flowers)"라고 직접적으로 꽃을 레스토랑 주인에 비유하고 있다.
해설: 텍스트에 따르면 "In the natural world, there are no neon signs or flashy words in which to market a potential meal to hungry animals."라고 명확히 언급되어 있다.
해설: 텍스트에서는 "the potential guests are the host of organisms that visit flowers to obtain nectar and other valuable resources"라고 설명하며, 동물들이 꽃을 방문하는 주된 이유는 꿀과 다른 귀중한 자원을 얻기 위함이라고 언급한다.
해설: 텍스트의 마지막 문장에서 "Instead of using a written language or neon sign, they advertise their offerings just as effectively using the language of smell."라고 명시하고 있다.

annotations.html:
(1) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면, "Most people will opt for the larger sum in thirteen months"라고 명시되어 있다. 대부분의 사람들은 1년 후 $1,000보다 13개월 후 $1,100을 선택한다.
(2) 해설: 텍스트에서 "where else will you find a monthly interest rate of 10 percent"라고 언급하고 있다. $1,000에서 $1,100로 증가하는 것은 한 달 동안 10%의 이자율에 해당한다.
(3) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면, "If you think like most people, you'll take the $1,000 right away"라고 명시되어 있다. 대부분의 사람들은 한 달을 기다려 $1,100을 받기보다 즉시 $1,000를 선택한다.
(4) 해설: 텍스트에서 하이퍼볼릭 할인(hyperbolic discounting)은 "The introduction of 'now' causes us to make inconsistent decisions"라고 설명하고 있다. 이는 일관되지 않은 결정을 내리는 현상을 의미한다.
(5) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면, "The closer a reward is, the higher our 'emotional interest rate' rises"라고 명시되어 있다. 보상이 더 즉각적일수록 우리의 "감정적 이자율"은 증가한다.
